Pd-Based are emerging as promising anode and cathode electrocatalysts for direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) owing to their high energy density and relatively low cost. However, their commercial application is limited due to some critical issues, such as sluggish kinetics, weak resistance to CO intermediate species and poor long-term stability. Therefore, it’s crucial to develop catalysts with well-designed structures that can be recycled to achieve outstanding electrocatalytic performance. In this study, we successfully introduced a facile and reliable approach to develop a modified multi-walled carbon nanotubes supported Bi/Trimetallic Pd-M/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-M-M/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts (M = Cd and Sn) by using mixture of ethylene glycol/water (3:1) and NaBH4 as reducing agents and citric acid as structure redirecting agents. Thanks to the synergetic effects and enriched robust bonding between Pd-Cd-Sn-C, Pd-Cd-C, Pd-Sn-C and Pd-C, which strongly promotes the obtaining of unique well-organized structures with uniform metals distribution, high CO anti-tolerance and long-term MOR stability. The optimized hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst exhibits superior catalytic activity (4561.96 mA mg−1) compared to Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs (2845.50 mA mg−1) and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (2142.61 mA mg−1) nanocatalysts, which is 8.7 times higher than commercial Pt/C (519.52 mA mg−1). Moreover, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs also exhibit remarkable stability and high catalytic activity even after the 140,000 s. This investigation showed unique Pd-based nanocatalysts with extraordinary MOR performance, which can provide valuable insights into the practical application of DMFCs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon nanotubes Facile synthesis strategy High stable catalysts Methanol electrooxidation Pd-based catalysts List of abbreviations Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) Direct Alcohol fuel cells (DAFCs) Methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) Double functional multi walled carbon nanotubes (Df-MWCNTs) High resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR) X-ray diffraction (XRD) Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fossil fuels have been widely used as the main energy source that fulfills the global demand [1–3]. However, the continuous utilization of fossil fuels leads to serious environmental issues [4]. Therefore, it is super essential to develop clean, cost-effective and renewable energy sources to replace fossil energy. Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have been recognized as one of the most promising candidates for energy conversion field to replace fossil energy due to their high energy density, low operation temperature, cost efficiency, and convenient to storage and transport [5–8]. Nevertheless, the sluggish kinetics of methanol electrooxidation (MOR) due to the formation of various intermediate species (COads and CHx) and structural deformation of catalysts during MOR process restrict their practical applications [9–11]. These limitations are primarily due to adsorbed CO poisoning on catalyst surface which leads to coverage of its active sites and inhibit performance [12–14]. Therefore, considerable efforts have been directed to the fabrication of cheap and high-performance non-Platinum (Pt) catalysts toward MOR process [15–17]. Palladium (Pd) and Pd-based catalysts are considered the most promising alternative to Pt nanocatalysts, due to their good physicochemical properties and relatively low cost [18–21]. Nevertheless, the inherent electronic structure of single unmodified Palladium and serious agglomeration of Pd during preparation are the reasons for not achieving high MOR electrocatalytic performance [22–24]. For instance, Pd-O has strong binding strength, which makes it difficult to achieve increased electrocatalytic activity for MOR process [25]. To overcome these challenges, different synthetic strategies such as: face control, defect engineering, strain engineering, and incorporation of other elements have been deeply studied to modify the surface and electronic structures of Pd and obtain catalyst with zero aggregation and enhanced MOR performance [26–33]. Recently, incorporation of Pd with other metals, such as Se, Ni, P, Fe, Bi, Te and Ag, has gathered a lot of attention for methanol electrooxidation due to their positive influence on enhancing Pd electronic structure and regulate the d-band center of Pd to expose more active sites, which benefit the overall MOR performance [34–37]. Moreover, Alloying Pd with other oxygenophilic metals such as Ir, Ru, Co, Au, Cd and Sn, can facilitate the dissociation of water to generate hydroxides functional groups (like OH* and OOH*) and obtain Pd-based nanocatalysts with high ability to speed up the elimination of intermediate species on Pd surface, thereby significantly enhancing MOR process [21,38–40]. For instance, Wang and his co-workers demonstrated that a well-designed self-supporting Pd-Ag nanoporous had a high MOR activity (1451.16 mA mg−1) compared to the Pd/C (180 mA mg−1), due to the successful dealloying strategy of Pd and Ag atoms, which helps in optimizing unique catalyst structure with high surface area, reduce the adsorption of CO intermediate species and enhanced MOR performance [41]. Rong et al., concluded that the regulation of surface defects Pd-based nanocrystals can facilitate the digestion of all CO-poisoning species and increase catalytic activity while maintaining high stability [42]. Moreover, different shape and size engineering nanostructured of Pd-based alloy nanocatalysts such as (core-shell, nanofibers, nanocages, among others) incorporated with carbon-based functional supports have been explored to modulate MOR and DMFCs [8,43–46]. Even though carbon materials are widely recognized supports for noble Pd-based catalysts nanocatalysts, their direct usage in electrocatalytic processes are difficult due to their high degree of graphitization, which renders them chemically inert by nature [47,48]. Therefore, it's critical to modify (functionalized) the surface of carbon materials to reduce the degree of graphitization and promote their ability to capture metals. Sikeyi et al., successfully developed functionalized nitrogen-doped onion-like carbons Pd/Ag/NOLCN and Pd/ZnO/NOLCN nanocatalysts via sodium borohydride reduction strategy with high electrochemical activity, excellent anti-poisoning tolerance, and long-term stability towards MOR in alkaline medium [29,49]. Huang et al [50], synthesized Two-dimensional (2D) Pd nanosheet-based catalysts with excellent methanol oxidation performance due to the unique obtained structure with high surface area. Lan Yue and his colleges devolved Palladium Nanocrystals within covalent organic framework-Intercalated MXene nanoarchitectures Pd/COF-MX with good MOR performance [51]. Although considerable progress has been made in the past few years, exploring advanced anode electrocatalysts with stable structures and excellent performance capable of solving DMFCs issues, more investigations are still needed to give deep understanding to the catalyst optimization and MOR mechanism on Pd-based catalysts [52,53]. Therefore, it's quite important to develop a facile and novel synthesis approach to fabricate Pd-based nanocatalysts with unique nanostructures and rich surfaces with cost effective strategy. In this work, we outline a promising approach for the rational development of modified multi-walled carbon nanotubes supported Bi/Ternary Pd-Based nanocatalysts (Pd-M/df-MWCNTs and Pd-M-M/df-MWCNTs, M = Cd and Sn) via facile room-temperature co-reduction synthesis strategy for methanol oxidation reaction (MOR). The MWCNTs play as a catalyst and uniformly dispersed carrier for the hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn catalyst with high stability. Moreover, MWCNTs helps in maximizing the ECSA of the catalyst due to the existence of oxygenated functional groups which facilitate the dispersion of Pd, Cd, and Sn atoms with strong carbon-metal bonds, leading to shortened charge transfer distances. Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs provide more surface-active sites, high electrocatalytic activity and super long-term stability for MOR. The electro-catalytic activity of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (4561.96 mA mg−1) is 8.7 times than that of commercial Pt/C (519.52 mA mg−1), attributed to the unique well-dispersed structure, generated reactive oxygen-containing radicals, and strong ability to remove CO-poisoning species from Pd surface. The selection of cadmium (Cd) and tin (Sn) as alloying elements in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts can enhance catalytic performance due to several reasons. (i) Cd and Sn can modify the electronic properties of Pd, improving its catalytic activity and selectivity for methanol electrooxidation. (ii) the alloying elements as well can increase the stability of Pd nanoparticles, ensuring catalytic performance sustained over time. (iii), Sn can facilitate the elimination of CO poisoning species, which is crucial for methanol oxidation reaction [54]. This study not only proposes a solution to the sluggish kinetic of MOR but also introduced a novel facile synthesis technique for advanced Pd-based nanocatalysts with unique structure and high ECSA, offering significant insights into the large-scale application of DMFCs. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Multi walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs 99.9 %, inner diameter of 5–12 nm and outer diameter of 30–50 nm), Palladium (II) chloride (PdCl2, 99.99 %), Tin (II) chloride (SnCl2, 99.98 %), Cadmium (II) chloride (CdCl2, 99.89 %), Acetone (C3H6O, 99.9 %), Methanol (CH3OH, 99.90 %) and Ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.99 %) were purchased from Aladdin Ltd (Shanghai, China). Ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, 99.50 %), Nafion (0.5 wt. %), Sodium borohydride (NaBH4, AR), Potassium hydroxide (KOH, 99.999 %) and Citric acid (C6H8O7, 99.0 %) were obtained from Sigma Aldrich Co., Ltd. Other chemicals, such as Sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 99.5 %), Nitric acid (HNO3, 99 %) and Indole-2-carboxylic acid (C9H7NO2, 98.0 %) were purchased from the Shanghai Chemical Factory (Shanghai, China). All aqueous solutions were prepared using ultrapure water (Millipore-3Q, 18.2 MX cm). All chemicals used in this study are commercially available and used as received without any further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Functionalization of MWCNTs MWCNTs were treated with a strong mixed acid of HNO3 and H2SO4 (3/1, v/v) to modify the surface and generate hydroxylic functional groups. The details process are as follows: 400 mg of MWCNTs were dissolved in 200 mL mixed acids (HNO3 =120 mL, H2SO4=40 mL and H2O=40 mL) and kept under ultra-sonication for 35 min, then transferred to oil bath and kept at 80 °C for 12 h. Then the black solution was washed with 2 L ultrapure water in a vacuum filtration unit, until neutral. The obtained carbon solution was dried in a vacuum oven at 70 °C overnight. To obtain extra carboxylic functional group on MWCNTs, 300 mg of functionalized f-MWCNTs were dissolved in 150 mL mixed solution of acetone and ethanol (2/1, v/v). Then 100 mg of Indole-2-carboxylic acid (C9H7NO2) was dissolved in 20 mL water and introduced to above mixture under high stirring at 55 °C for 8 h. The final product was washed carefully with ultrapure water in a vacuum filtration unit and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. 2.2.2 Preparation of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTS Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts were synthesized via facile co-reduction synthesis strategy and the detail process as follows: 3 mL of Palladium (II) chloride PdCl2 (0.06 M) was added to mixture solution containing 100 mL Ethylene Glycol (solvent/reducing agent), 10 mL water and 80 mg of citric acid, and kept under high stirring at room temperature (RT) for 30 min. Then 80 mg of the support (Df-MWCNTs) was dispersed in 5 ml of H2O and sonicated for 15 min and introduced to the above solution. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 12 by adding 5 mL NaOH (1 M). Subsequently, 0.6 mL of Cadmium (II) chloride CdCl2 (0.06 M) and 0.8 mL of Tin (II) chloride SnCl2 (0.06 M) were added to the Df-MWCNTs solution and kept under constant stirring to obtain homogenous black mixed solution. Then, 90 mg of sodium borohydride (NaBH4) was dispersed in 10 ml of water and sonicated for 10 min and added to the black mixed solution and kept under high stirring at RT for 14 h. Finally, the obtained catalysts were centrifuged and washed carefully 4 times with ethanol and 4 times with ultrapure water and dried in an oven at 60 °C for overnight. A similar procedure was employed for the synthesis of bimetallic Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts. 2.3 Physical and morphological characterizations Physical and morphological characterization along with elemental composition of as-prepared Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts were investigated by various characterization techniques. The crystalline nature, phase compositions and particles size of the as-prepared catalysts were determined via X-ray diffraction device (XRD, Philips analytical diffractometer). To obtain X-ray diffraction patterns, all XRD measurements were carried out with a SEIFERT 2000 diffractometer using CuK radiation (λ = 0.1540 nm) produced at 35 kV, scan rate of 10 min−1 and 30 mA and potential values between 2 and 90° FT-IR spectroscopy was conducted using a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FT-IR, Shimadzu-8400, Japan) to identify the existence of functional groups. Raman spectrum of all prepared catalysts was performed via Raman spectrometer HORIBA Jobin Yvon Lab RAM HR (532 nm He–Ne laser) at wavenumber range of 400–4000 cm−1. Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) and Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) with a Bruker XFlash 6130 were used to examine the surface morphology of all the produced catalysts. Transmission electron microscope (TEM & HR-TEM) Purchased from Philips-FEI, Eindhoven-Netherland was used to investigate the morphology and determine the particles sizes of prepared catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo scientific™ K-Alpha™+, USA) was performed to evaluate the elements content and composition of as-prepared catalysts. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical measurements were performed at room temperature using CHI700E electrochemical workstation. Standard three-electrode cell systems were used including: (i) glassy carbon (GC) with a diameter of 5 mm and geometric area of 0.0707 cm2 was used as working electrode, which is coated with the catalyst. (ii) A platinum plate served as the counter electrode (auxiliary), which is used to make a direct connection with the electrolyte for the purpose of applying a current to the working electrode. (iii) The reference electrode consists of mercury/mercury oxide (Hg/HgO, MMO, E0 = 0.22 V vs. RHE). The surface of the glassy carbon (GC) electrode was polished using a 0.3 μm and 0.05 mm alumina slurry followed by washing with deionized water and kept in ultrasonication for 20 min to remove any impurities. The ink catalyst was prepared according to previous report [55], the details process are as follows: 3.0 mg of the catalyst and 10 µL of a 5 % Nafion solution were dissolved in 1.5 mL of water and kept under sonication at RT for 40 min to generate a homogeneous black ink. Then 20 µL of black ink was dropped slowly into the surface of the working electrode (GC) and dried in an oven at 60 °C for 20 min to obtain uniform coated layer. To investigate activity and electrochemical active surface area ECSA of as-prepared catalysts, the samples were tested in N2-saturated 1.0 M KOH + 1.0 M methanol at a potential range from −0.8 to 0.6 V and scan rate of 50 mV s-1. To investigate the catalysts stability chronoamperometric (CA) measurements were performed in a N2-saturated 1.0 M KOH + 1.0 M CH3OH at −0.2 V for 7000 s. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure characterization The hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts were successfully synthesized via facile wet chemical reaction strategy (Fig. 1 a). Initially, the surface of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) was cleared and deactivated using strong mixture acid strategy (HNO3 and H2SO4) to obtain nitrogen and oxygen-containing functional groups. Then double functionalization of MWCNTs were done via Indole-2-carboxylic acid (C9H7NO2) to obtain extra carboxylic functional groups, which can facilitate the metals to load on MWCNTs surface. Finally, the metals Pd, Cd and Sn were uniformly dispersed on Df-MWCNTs through co-reduction synthesis technique to obtain well-organized hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts with ultra-small size and high surface area. The morphology, structure and size elemental distribution of hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts were deeply investigated using Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) attached with Energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). The TEM images Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs at 100 nm magnification in Fig. 1b show a homogeneous distribution of Pd, Cd and Sn nanoparticles well integrated with multi-walled carbon nanotubes (Df-MWCNTs). The high-resolution HRTEM image of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs at various magnifications (20, 10 and 5 nm) as described in Fig. 1c-d confirms that the Pd, Cd and Sn nanostructure are well-dispersed and interconnected within (outside and inside) the network of Df-MWCNTs with small particle size (3 nm in average) and high surface area. The HRTEM images in Figure S1 (supporting information) reveal the well-defined crystallographic plane of Pd (111) in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs with an interplanar distance of 0.24 nm. This observed regular pattern of atoms aligned at the lattice structure further validates the enhancement in structure of Pd NPs due to the influence of incorporated metals such as Cd and Sn nanoparticles. High magnification SEM image of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs as shown in Fig. 1e confirms that the metals are uniformly distributed on every part of MWCNTs surface with high loading. To further confirm the elemental distribution, EDS elemental mappings Images of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs are shown in Fig. 1f and Figure S2. It shows that C (blue), Pd (green), Cd (pink) and Sn (yellow) elements are well-organized and uniformly distributed, which demonstrated the well-defined unique structure and high surface area of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts. Moreover, SEM images of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNT, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts display uniform metal dispersion in every part of the figure with high loading and less aggregation compared to the high aggregated Single-metallic Pd/Df-MWCNTs catalyst (Figure S3). Elemental distribution and EDS mappings Images of Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts also confirmed the high metal dispersion on MWCNTs with unique uniform structure (Figure S4 and Figure S5). 3.2 Physicochemical characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted to further investigate the phase and crystal composition of all prepared catalysts (Fig. 2 a). The observed diffraction spectra between 20–30 corresponds to (002) face of carbon, which indicates the existence of MWCNTs. The Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts show unique diffraction peaks patterns at 2θ values of 40.11°, 46.55°, 68.42° and 81.82°, which correspond to the crystal planes of Pd (111), Pd (200), Pd (220), and Pd (311), respectively. This demonstrates that the Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts were synthesized to fit within the standard face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure [56]. It is found through analyzed spectrum of pure Pd (JCPDS file No.46–1043), all catalysts diffraction peaks lie within equivalent peaks of pure Pd, indicating the formation of alloy between Pd, Cd, and Sn. Moreover, Pd (111) diffraction peaks of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts were shifted slightly to a lower angle, suggesting that Cd and Sn were successfully doped, which contributed to the modification of the electronic structure of Pd and increased its lattice spacing. The expansion of the lattice will reduce the interaction strength among Pd atoms, which facilitates the adsorption of methanol and enhancing overall MOR process. Raman spectroscopy was performed to further study the physical properties of all prepared catalysts (Fig. 2b and Figure S6). The D peak in the Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs is stronger than those of Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd/Df-MWCNTs and Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts, which is due to the existent of high oxygen vacancies in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs. Moreover, a positive shift happened in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (1572.38 cm–1) compared to Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs (1569.56 cm–1) and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (1571.81 cm–1) which indicates the successful incorporation of Cd and Sn, because the incorporated metals are responsible for the change in the lattice deformation of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs. Therefore, Raman characterization demonstrates that more and more oxygen vacancies are generated in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, which facilitate the removal of CO-like species from Pd surface and enhance the overall MOR process. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were conducted to further investigate the composition, bonding structure and functional groups on carbon to better understand the synergistic energy-effect between C and Pd of all prepared catalysts as illustrated in Figure 3(a-g). Various characteristic peaks appear in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, indicating the existence of C 1 s, Pd 3d, Cd 3d, Sn 3d, N 1 s, and O 1 s (Fig. 3 a). The high-resolution Pd 3d spectra of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts were shown in Fig. 3b The Pd 3d5/2 consists of two peaks at 335.66 eV for Pd (0) and 337.38 eV for Pd (II), whereas Pd 3d3/2 were represented by the peaks at 340.80 eV for Pd (0) and 342.55 eV for Pd (II), which confirms most of Pd+2 was fully reduced to Pd atoms. In addition, the Pd3d5/2 of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (335.66 eV) slightly shifted to higher BE value compared to Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs (335.63 eV) and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (335.24 eV), due to the incorporation of Cd and Sn, which gradually lowers the coordination of Pd and modifies its electrical structure (Table S1). These findings, which are in good agreement with the XRD and Raman data, clearly demonstrated the positive modification in Pd electrical structure. As displayed in Fig. 3c, the peaks value of Cd 3d5/2 and Cd 3d3/2 in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs are located at 404.31 eV and 412.09 eV correspond to Cd (0), which confirms all Cd+2 was fully reduced to Cd atoms. The XPS spectrum with high resolution for Sn3d in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalyst is displayed in Fig. 3d Two peaks are identified, exhibiting binding energies of 486.62 eV (Sn3d5/2) and 495.13 eV (Sn3d3/2) corresponding to Sn (0). The C1s spectra in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs show three fitting peaks: 284.47 eV, 284.68 eV and 286.59 eV corresponding to C = O, C = C and O C = O, respectively (Fig. 3e). The O1s spectra shows two peaks at 533.15 eV and 531.93 eV is primarily attributed to the COH and oxygen vacancy (Fig. 3f). The N1s XPS spectrum in Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs revealed two peaks: graphitic-N at 404.23 eV and oxygenated-N at 405.48 eV (Fig. 3 g). The FT-IR spectra of Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Cd-Sn/MWCNTs nanocatalysts displayed four different peaks appear at 574.73cm-1, 1383.61 cm-1, 1632.30 cm-1, 3346.24 cm-1 are attributed to following functional groups: COOH, CH3, -C = O/CC, and OH, respectively. Indicating the successful double functionalization process of Df-MWCNTs (Fig. 3h). 3.3 Electrochemical studies Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and CO-stripping tests were conducted to investigate the electrochemical performance of as-prepared catalysts (Fig. 4 a-d). The CV curves for hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Sn/Df-MCNTs, Pd/Df-MWCNTs and commercial Pt/C nanocatalysts were tested in N2-saturated 1 M KOH solution (Fig. 4a-b). During anodic scanning, the adsorption and oxidation of hydroxyl groups on Palladium take place within the voltage range of 0.5 to 0.1 V, as illustrated in the following equations. (1) Pd + OH- → Pd-OH + e - (2) Pd-OH ads + OH ads →Pd-O + H2O + e - The observed peaks range between −0.2 and −0.6 V correspond to the PdO reduction. The peak current density (PdO) of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalyst during forward scanning exhibits high value compared to that of commercial Pd/C, indicating the potential of incorporated metals (Cd & Sn) in the displacement reaction. (3) Pd-OH ads + Cd ↔ Pd + Cd-OH ads (4) Pd-OH ads + Sn ↔ Pd + Sn-OH ads (5) PdO + Cd → Pd +CdO (6) PdO + Sn → Pd + SnO Fig. 4c illustrates the digestion and removal of adsorbed CO-poisoning species from Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, Pd/Df-MWCNTs and commercial Pt/C nanocatalysts using COads stripping voltammetry in CO-saturated KOH (1 M) electrolyte. Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs exhibit super high COads stripping voltammogram as compared to Pt/C and other catalysts demonstrated it’s the high CO anti-poisoning ability due to the unique well-designed structures, high surface area and the positive influence of incorporated Cd and Sn. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of as-prepared catalysts were determined directly from the peak charge of PdO and Pd-CO reduction areas according to the following equations [57]. (7) ECSA ( PdO ) = Q ( PdO ) 0.405 * V * M (8) ECSA ( PdCO ) = Q ( PdCO ) 0.405 * V * M Where, Q is the charge of Pd-O and Pd-CO reduction, which can be calculated from the area of the PdO and PdCO reduction peaks in the integrated CV curve, 0.405 is the voltage needed to reduce a PdO and PdCO monolayer (mC), V is the scan rate used in the CV (50 mV·s −1), and M is the overall quantity of loaded elements (catalyst) onto the working electrode. The normalized ECSAPd-O value of all prepared catalysts was as follows: Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (153.09 m2 g-1) > Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs (77.47 m2 g-1) >Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (73.11 m2 g-1) > Pd/Df-MWCNTs (65.51 m2 g-1) > commercial Pt/C (29.61 m2 g-1). Moreover, the normalized CO-stripping ECSAPd-CO were 106.54, 72.09, 79.28, 24.31, and 10.38 m2 g-1 corresponding to Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd/Df-MWCNTs and commercial Pt/C, respectively (Fig. 4d and Table S2). To further explore the MOR electrocatalytic activity of as-prepared Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd/Df-MWCNTs and commercial Pt/C nanocatalysts, CV measurements were performed in a mixture of 1 M KOH + 1 M CH3OH electrolyte as displayed in Figure (5a-b). The MOR CV curve of as-prepared catalysts shows two typical characteristic peaks: the forward scanning peak (If) ranges between −0.4 to 0.4 and the backward scanning peak (Ib) ranges between −0.44 to −0.1 V. These peaks represent the current density values of adsorbed methanol molecules when the CO bond breaks during MOR process. This includes the oxidation of freshly adsorbed methanol and the strong removal of residual carbon compounds like COads from the Pd surface. The hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (4561.96 mA mg−1) nanocatalyst present the highest mass activity among Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs (2845.50 mA mg−1), Pd-Sn/Df-WCNTs 2142.61 mA mg−1), and Pd/Df-MWCNTs (1475.38 mA mg−1), which is 8.7 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C (JM) catalyst (519.52 mA mg−1), due to the well-organized structure with well-metal dispersion and ultra-high ECSA (Fig. 5 a). Similarly, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs have the lowest initial potential, suggesting that electrocatalytic methanol oxidation has easily happened in present of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalyst with fast catalytic reaction kinetics due to the huge surface-active sites (Fig. 5b). Therefore, the MOR mass activity of as-prepared catalysts was arranged according to the following order: Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs > Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs > Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs > Pd/Df-MWCNTs > commercial Pt/C (Table S2). In summary, these findings showed that Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalysts have higher MOR activity compared to commercial Pt/C, because the incorporated Cd and Sn atoms modified the electronic structure of Pd, as confirmed by the XPS spectra, and the binding energy of MOR intermediates was weakened. MOR electrocatalytic stability were assessed via chronoamperometric measurements (0–7000 s) for as-prepared Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts and compared with Pd/Df-MWCNTs and commercial Pt/C NPs (Fig. 5c-d). The current density of all prepared catalysts decreased quickly in the initial stage due to generation of high amount of CO-intermediate species during MOR, which absorbed on Pd surface and poisoned its active sites (Fig. 5c) [58]. Over time, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs exhibit the highest residual current density value and the slowest pattern of normalized current density decline, indicating that CO-poisoning species are less absorbed on the catalyst surface (Fig. 5d). After 7000 s test, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs exhibits superior current density (1008.48 mA mg−1) than those of Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs (393.88 mA mg−1), Pd-Sn/Df-Df-MWCNTs (337.86 mA mg−1), while Pd/Df-MWCNTs, and commercial Pt/C were super low almost inactive after 3000 s. Hence, the residual current stability value of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs is 1008.48 mA mg−1, which is 9 times stable than Pt/C (112.05 mA mg−1), demonstrating the strong electrocatalytic stability of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst towards MOR. Moreover, our produced Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst also outperforms the majority of previously and recently reported Pd-based nanocatalysts in terms of MOR electrocatalytic activity, excellent CO-anti tolerance, and super-long stability under mild conditions (Fig. 5e and Table S4) [59–64]. To further investigate the recyclability of as-prepared catalysts, 9 continues CA stability cycles were performed for Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts (Fig. 6 a-d).The Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalyst exhibits excellent stability even after 9 cycles, due to the synergistic effects of its alloy components and Df-MWCNTs (Fig. 6a). Moreover, Cd and Sn NPs contribute to the structural stability and improve its corrosion resistance. In addition, the incorporation Cd and Sn NPs not only enhance the electronic structure but also obtain catalyst with less structural dissolution and no degradation during MOR process. As shown in Fig. 6b, the stability degradation in Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs is a little high compared to Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWNCTs, indicating less recyclability of bi-metallic. After four cycles, Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs showed a rapid stability decrease and that lasted until the catalyst ran inactive (Fig. 6c). Therefore, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst is ultra stable even after 9 cycles and can be recycled, which makes it suitable for large-scale DMFCs applications unlike Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalysts (Fig. 6d). Moreover, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs continued to have high ECSA (137.72 m2 g-1) and super high activity (4134.12 mA mg−1) even after 9 cycles, which confirmed the strong ability of our produced catalyst to eliminate all CO-like species from Pd surface and accelerate the kinetic of overall MOR process (Fig. 6e-f). Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts displayed less ECSA and relatively low catalytic activity after 9 stability cycles compared to Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalyst (Figure S7). To ensure catalyst recyclability, CA test was performed in a mixture solution of 1 M KOH and MeOH for super-long time (140,000 s). Even though Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst demonstrates a significant current density value and outstanding electrocatalytic activity after 140,000 s of CA testing, due to its remarkable recycling capability (Fig. 7 a-b). The schematic summary of the reaction mechanism for the oxidation and degradation of methanol on Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs catalyst is described in Fig. 8 and Figure S8. Methanol initially absorbs onto Pd and the support surface. An extra flux of reactants from/to the active Pd particles could result from the diffusion and spillover of molecular methanol and methoxy molecules. Methanol breaks down by first forming methoxy (CH3O) species, which are then followed by the splitting of either the C–H or C–O bonds lead to coverage of catalyst surface. Formaldehyde (CH2O), formyl (CHO), and CO are the products of C–H bond scission. In the presence of extra adsorbed oxygenated compounds (OH) due to the influence of Cd and Sn nanoparticle facilitate the production of CO2 and H2O by removal of all CO species from catalyst active cites, leading to excellent MOR performance (Eq. (7)–12). (7a) Pd + CH3OH→ Pd-CH3OHads + H + + e − (8a) Pd-CH3OHads + OH− → Pd-(CH2O) ads + H2O + e − (9) Pd-(CH2O) ads + OH− → Pd-(CHO) ads + H2O + e − (10) Pd-(CHO) ads → Pd-COads + e − (11) Cd + Sn + 2H2O → Cd-OH ads + Sn-OH ads +2H+ + 2e− (12) Cd-OH ads + Sn-OH ads + 2Pd-COads → Pd + Cd + 2CO2 + 2H++ 2e− 4 Conclusion In summary, we introduced a facile and reliable approach for the development of modified multi-walled carbon nanotubes supporting Pd-based nanocatalysts by doping Pd, Cd and Sn atoms on Df-MWCNTs for methanol electrooxidation. A series of well-dispersed Bi/trimetallic hybrid Pd-based nanocatalysts with ultrafine structures and high surface area were obtained, including Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts. The presence of Cd and Sn atoms positively enhances the electronic structure and amorphous interfaces of Pd nanocatalysts, which provide huge surface-active sites and enhanced MOR performance. In addition, the existence of Df-MWCNTs also contributed to increased overall surface area of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs. The well-dispersed hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst with high ECSA offers quick routes for the movement of inter-electrons from Df-MWCNTs to the active metals (Pd, Cd and Sn) and significantly speeds up the mass-transfer rate during MOR process. Thus, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs displayed the highest electrocatalytic activity, good ability to eliminate CO-poisoning species, and super long stability compared to Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs, Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs, and commercial Pt/C nanocatalysts. The superior MOR performance of Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst is due to the following: (i) The interconnected Cd and Sn contribute positively to enhance electronic structures and modify the d-band center of Pd that provide more active sites, which facilitate the mass-charge transfer and reduce the resistance, thereby enhancing overall MOR process. (ii) The existence of oxygenated functional groups in Df-MWCNTs and the generated OH- by Cd and Sn atoms are essential for eliminating CO poisoning from the catalytic active sites. (iii) The Pd-CO bond is weakened by the synergistic interaction between metals and Df-MWCNTs as well as between metals. This study presents an innovative synthetic route for the fabrication of carbon-supported Pd-based catalysts from material composition to structural design, which significantly accelerates the practical application of DMFCs and beyond. coredata.dc:description: Pd-Based are emerging as promising anode and cathode electrocatalysts for direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) owing to their high energy density and relatively low cost. However, their commercial application is limited due to some critical issues, such as sluggish kinetics, weak resistance to CO intermediate species and poor long-term stability. Therefore, it’s crucial to develop catalysts with well-designed structures that can be recycled to achieve outstanding electrocatalytic performance. In this study, we successfully introduced a facile and reliable approach to develop a modified multi-walled carbon nanotubes supported Bi/Trimetallic Pd-M/Df-MWCNTs and Pd-M-M/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalysts (M = Cd and Sn) by using mixture of ethylene glycol/water (3:1) and NaBH4 as reducing agents and citric acid as structure redirecting agents. Thanks to the synergetic effects and enriched robust bonding between Pd-Cd-Sn-C, Pd-Cd-C, Pd-Sn-C and Pd-C, which strongly promotes the obtaining of unique well-organized structures with uniform metals distribution, high CO anti-tolerance and long-term MOR stability. The optimized hybrid Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs nanocatalyst exhibits superior catalytic activity (4561.96 mA mg−1) compared to Pd-Cd/Df-MWCNTs (2845.50 mA mg−1) and Pd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs (2142.61 mA mg−1) nanocatalysts, which is 8.7 times higher than commercial Pt/C (519.52 mA mg−1). Moreover, Pd-Cd-Sn/Df-MWCNTs also exhibit remarkable stability and high catalytic activity even after the 140,000 s. This investigation showed unique Pd-based nanocatalysts with extraordinary MOR performance, which can provide valuable insights into the practical application of DMFCs.
